content: The "Law Enforcement Science and Technology Act of 2000" establishes an Office of Science and Technology under the Department of Justice, headed by a director from the Senior Executive Service. The functions and employees of the National Institute of Justice's Office of Science and Technology are transferred to this new Office. The "Law Enforcement Science and Technology Act of 2000" establishes an Office of Science and Technology under the Department of Justice, with a director from the Senior Executive Service. The functions and employees of the National Institute of Justice's Office of Science and Technology are transferred to this new Office. The mission of the Office is defined in Section 3, outlining its duties. The Office of Science and Technology under the Department of Justice serves as the national focal point for law enforcement technology. It improves technology access for law enforcement agencies and provides recommendations to the Attorney General. Advisory groups assess technology needs, establish standards, and test technologies for law enforcement agencies. The Office of Science and Technology under the Department of Justice works with law enforcement agencies to certify products, establish standards, and conduct research to improve technology used by Federal, State, and local law enforcement. This includes developing weapons, protective gear, monitoring systems, and alarm systems for precise location information. The Office of Science and Technology under the Department of Justice works with law enforcement agencies to improve technology used by Federal, State, and local law enforcement. This includes providing precise location information, wire and wireless communication technologies, tools for forensic work, equipment for counterterrorism, guides for law enforcement agencies, DNA identification technologies, and tools for investigating computer crime. They also administer a program to enhance voice and data public safety communications interoperability and serve on the Technical Support Working Group. The Office of Science and Technology under the Department of Justice works with law enforcement agencies to improve technology used by Federal, State, and local law enforcement. They serve on the Technical Support Working Group, develop and disseminate technical assistance and training materials, operate regional technology centers, support research fellowships, serve as a clearinghouse for information on law enforcement technologies, and represent the United States in international activities concerning law enforcement technology. The Office of Science and Technology under the Department of Justice has the authority to enter contracts, provide grants, and carry out duties assigned by the Attorney General. Federal agencies must provide requested data and information to the Office. The Director has sole authority over publications, and the Office can transfer funds to other agencies or non-Federal entities for its duties. SEC. 4. AUTHORIZATION OF APPROPRIATIONS. In fiscal years 2000 through 2005, $200,000,000 is authorized to be appropriated for the Office. Set-asides include $40,000,000 for National Law Enforcement and Corrections Technology Centers, $60,000,000 for forensic technology research, $20,000,000 for technology standards development, $10,000,000 for salaries and expenses, and up to 5% for Intergovernmental Personnel Act expenditures. The Intergovernmental Personnel Act of 1970 and the Systems Engineering and Technical Assistance program allocate 75 percent of funds for non-Federal research and development through a competitive process. If less than $200,000,000 is appropriated for the Office in fiscal years 2001 through 2005, reductions will be made in specified areas. If less than $200,000,000 is appropriated for the Office in fiscal years 2001 through 2005, amounts in subsection (b)(1), (2), and (3) shall be reduced proportionally. The Director of the Office must submit an annual report on law enforcement technology to the President and Congress by February 1 each year. Law enforcement technology includes investigative, forensic, corrections, and judicial support technologies.
